intro: Oxytropis sylvatica, commonly known as the redstem locoweed, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and trifoliate leaves. The plant produces small, pea-like flowers that range in color from purple to white, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It is adapted to dry, rocky habitats and has a deep root system that helps it survive in arid conditions. Oxytropis sylvatica is also known for its toxic properties, containing alkaloids that can be harmful to livestock.
